posts.author: Phazael
posts.body:
Dawn of Mankind is part of a new trend of smaller box games with a lot of crunch to them, in the same vein as the Epic and Age of _ series. It is modestly priced and comes in a smaller box, though not as small as the aforementioned series. Our group plays games regularly with Root, Hansa Teutanica, Cthulhu Wars, and Beyond the Sun being among our favorites. This week I brought this gem to the table.

Presentation-
The art is simple, but gets the job done. I have heard people complain about the meeple markers, but honestly every item is both a specific shape and color to denote its role in the game. Once you understand their symbol system, visual analysis of the board is very easy and straightforward. The art, while muted, fits the theme very well of your tribe spreading out into the world to advance its knowledge, gather food, and expand. It also has a very modest table footprint compared to many similar games, being both easier to organize and more compact during play than many of these other smaller gamebox games.

Mechanics-
This is where the game excels. It is a worker placement, but with constant bumping of your tribe as each player competes for important action. The rounds are continuous, meaning no clean up phase after X workers are placed or some such, just constant actions being taken with a player occasionally resting to free up workers strategically. This has two major impacts on the game, both positive. First, there is almost no down time in this game, even with five players. Second, more workers does not translate into more action economy, simply more board presence and options. This second one is key, because one issue many worker placement games have is if one player builds up a bunch of workers early before the others they have an overwhelming action advantage. In this game, you will still want workers so that you can have more options and be bumped more often, but they are not essential to remain competitive, at least not directly. Infact, in larger games you will see players tone down how many of their workers are brought into play just to avoid having to bump constantly. It is very reminiscent of Beyond the Sun in this manner.

What is bumping? Well when you move a worker from a ready area (organized into lanes of more powerful actions) to an action space where another player's worker already exists, that player gets moved up into the next (and more advanced) ready space, freeing it up to take more powerful actions. It sounds competitive and chaotic, and on some levels it is, but really it just drives the pace of the game by encouraging players to balance their worker supply and bumping. The idea situation is to be in a constant state of being bumped and taking actions, minimizing how often you need to rest. It works very well and prevents the whole "I am blocked out of anything" situation a lot of other Worker Placement games suffer. Here, you can always take the action, but it may benefit an opponent. In this way, players are always doing something they want to develop their game state, comparable to games like Seven Wonders and Magna Roma, and not feeling trapped into dead turns.

Balancing this are a touch of resource management and art cards. Most actions, including the Art cards, require resources to activate. Thus you cannot simply focus on scoring points but must also be sure to constantly be gathering resources to sustain your scoring efforts. The art cards are essentially scoring cards for workers that age out with numerous options and twists to their value. The serve as one of the primary random elements in the game, since they are drawn at random and replaced as completed. The art cards are pricey enough to force real choices, but score enough to make them all desirable options if you can manage your resources to benefit from them. They are arguably the strongest aspect of the scoring mechanisms in this game.

Scoring is pretty straightforward, drawing tokens for your points as you go and then you can hide your current total if you wish. If a player reaches 60, the game ends immediately and a few bonus points (mostly based on techs you gain and remaining resources) are scored. In practice, the player ending the game tends to win since the other end game bonus points are modest, which is one of my main criticisms of the game. People with good memory will know the game state, but anyone else is in the dark and will be caught off guard by the game ending. I also think the techs need to have more post game value to justify the effort needed to secure them, particularly in higher player count games. Most of our games were won by people just resourcing and landing on the biggest VP spaces repeatedly and ignoring the techs all together. I feel like making the end game tech and resource points worth maybe double would open up some more play options beyond "I hit the 10VP square early and often". I think hiding the points is kind of silly too and maybe they should have gone with a token draw system for rewards where you draw X tokens and keep them hidden. Reason being, as someone with a good memory I knew how many points everyone had at all times. My wife, who is good at board games but not as good at memorization, struggled to track the game state.

Overall-
Those minor issues with scoring aside, I recommend this game strongly for anyone who likes WP games but hates action economy being a dominant element. If you like low downtime fast paced games, this will also sit well with your group. Finally, If you like Euro games of low complexity or are interested in simply trying a Euro style game for the first time, this is probably the best game you could choose to fit that role. Its simple enough to not overwhelm, requiring no rulebook referencing once setup is complete. But the strategy is pretty deep and player interaction is present without it being hyper competitive. I consider it a simpler more muted version of Beyond the Sun, which I mean as very high praise. Thanks to the randomization of action tiles and art cards, it also has a very high degree of replayability, something other Worker Placement games struggle to achieve. It is also very fast to set up, play, and pack up, moreso than any comparable game.

My rating for this game if I had to assign a number would be a 9.5 out of 10, with only the scoring balance holding it back from perfection.

posts.author: dr_draft
posts.body:
Hi Daniel,

Thanks for your question! We did indeed explore several options for tracking life, including traditional life trackers. In the end, we found that life tokens were the most convenient solution.

The main reason is that combat in the game is fast-paced, with damage typically ranging from 1 to 5 points. In practice, it was much quicker and easier to grab a few 1 or 5-point tokens than to constantly adjust a dial or wheel. Another advantage is visibility—tokens make it easy for everyone around the table to get a quick sense of how much life each character has left, which isn't as straightforward when players are using individual life trackers (which they have to pick up in order to adjust).

Hope that makes sense

Upon reading the rulebook, I noticed a couple of terms that I think could be clearer.

For example:

• “Counter” — To me, this always feels like it would deal damage back (like a counterattack). But since it doesn’t do that and simply prevents damage, my suggestion would be to call it something like ‘Prevent’, ‘Block’, or ‘Negate’ instead.

• “Coward” — I find this a bit harsh, as it directly characterises the person making that decision. It might be nice to replace this with something more neutral and commonly used in board games, like simply ‘Pass’ or ‘Skip’, for example.

I hope you can consider these suggestions.
